prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our primary goal is to obtain resolved images of the molecular lines of HCN and CO, with sufficient sensitivity and angular resolution to detect to a range of disk radii. While high-J lines in Band 9 can better sample modest radii (<10-20 AU), the observations are extremely challenging. Band 7 offers the best compromise to the full disk, and has an excellent suite of tracers that can be imaged in only two LO settings. In particular, the highest priority HCN 4-3 and CO 3-2 observations (with isotopologues) will provide abundance estimates for the mid- to outer-disk, and when combined with mid-IR HCN/CO data will constrain the C/O ratio between the terrestrial and ice giant planet-forming regions. As shown in Figures 3a/3c, the proposed observations should nicely detect and resolve the molecular emission. To optimize the integration time and scientific outcome, we propose to use 0."4 spatial resolution and integrate deeply enough to recover the line wings for Keplerian velocity-driven super-resolution reconstructions of the disk gas on 10-30 AU scales (Dutrey 2011). Higher angular resolution observations would likely more directly image/constrain such radii, but at the cost of considerably increased integration time. Specific technical details follow.
Requested sensitivity: The CO, 13CO, and HCO+ lines will be readily detectable (see Table 1). We thus base sensitivity requirements on HCN (and C18O), for which Oberg et al. (2010) report an unresolved 3-2 detection toward AA Tau using the SMA. The HCO+ 3-2 line flux is ~4 larger. No other HCN information is available, but from studies of other disks we expect fluxes within factors of 2-4 of 13CO. We model the HCN fluxes using a disk of mass 0.01 Msun and a constant HCN abundance scaled to match the observed HCN 3-2 line flux. Other disks are scaled according to their mm-continuum. This yields a predicted HCN 4-3 line with peak fluxes of 50 mJy/beam for AA Tau, in an ~0."4 beam. Results are shown in Fig. 3a. With ~20 min. of on source integration, the predicted sensitivity is 4 mJy-km s-1/beam in a 1 km/s bin. This would provide sufficiently high S/N on the HCN 4-3 and 13CO/C18O 3-2 lines to probe the line wings to radii well within those detected by previous interferometric observations. We expect comparable molecular line intensity in the other two sources.
Imaging requirements: These nearby disks are compact, and only require a single configuration to recover the available flux. One target, AA Tau, is modestly far north, but even with 20 minutes of integration time the resulting image fidelity is superb. Our Cycle 0 data show the remaining Oph disks will be beautifully imaged. Beyond the Cycle 0 data on AS 205N, we also present in Figure 3c a simulation of the AA Tau HCN observations requested, using the known flux from several arcsecond resolution SMA observations.
Correlator setup: The typical line widths are 2-5 km/s. Two correlator setups in Band 7 are used to observe the HCN and CO lines. The fist LO setting has two spectral windows (SPWs) with 0.2 km/s resolution on HCN and HCO+. One LSB window of the same width contains CO 3-2 and H13CN, and a broadband SPW will be used in the LSB to measure the continuum. Velocity resolution is unimportant here. In the second set up, LSB SPWs with 0.2 km/s resolution will be used for 13CO and C18O 3-2, with a similar USB SPW set up for CN 3-2, a bright and widely observed photochemistry tracer in disks and SO. The last SPW will be broad, both for continuum measurements and improved calibration. While SO line has not yet been detected in a protoplanetary disk, (sub)mm observations of molecular clouds shows that SO is typically half the intensity of similar excitation CS lines (Nilsson et al. 2000). This would yield another C/O constraint, independent of HCN, H2O, and CO (see Fig. 1 & Walsh et al. 2012).

Our primary goal is to obtain resolved images of the molecular lines of HCN and CO, with sufficient sensitivity and angular resolution to detect to a range of disk radii. While high-J lines in Band 9 can better sample modest radii (<10-20 AU), the observations are extremely challenging. Band 7 offers the best compromise to the full disk, and has an excellent suite of tracers that can be imaged in only two LO settings. In particular, the highest priority HCN 4-3 and CO 3-2 observations (with isotopologues) will provide abundance estimates for the mid- to outer-disk, and when combined with mid-IR HCN/CO data will constrain the C/O ratio between the terrestrial and ice giant planet-forming regions. As shown in Figures 3a/3c, the proposed observations should nicely detect and resolve the molecular emission. To optimize the integration time and scientific outcome, we propose to use 0."4 spatial resolution and integrate deeply enough to recover the line wings for Keplerian velocity-driven super-resolution reconstructions of the disk gas on 10-30 AU scales (Dutrey 2011). Higher angular resolution observations would likely more directly image/constrain such radii, but at the cost of considerably increased integration time. Specific technical details follow.
Requested sensitivity: The CO, 13CO, and HCO+ lines will be readily detectable (see Table 1). We thus base sensitivity requirements on HCN (and C18O), for which Oberg et al. (2010) report an unresolved 3-2 detection toward AA Tau using the SMA. The HCO+ 3-2 line flux is ~4 larger. No other HCN information is available, but from studies of other disks we expect fluxes within factors of 2-4 of 13CO. We model the HCN fluxes using a disk of mass 0.01 Msun and a constant HCN abundance scaled to match the observed HCN 3-2 line flux. Other disks are scaled according to their mm-continuum. This yields a predicted HCN 4-3 line with peak fluxes of 50 mJy/beam for AA Tau, in an ~0."4 beam. Results are shown in Fig. 3a. We expect comparable molecular line intensity in the other two sources.
Imaging requirements: These nearby disks are compact, and only require a single configuration to recover the available flux. One target, AA Tau, is modestly far north, but even with 20 minutes of integration time the resulting image fidelity is superb. Our Cycle 0 data show the remaining Oph disks will be beautifully imaged. Beyond the Cycle 0 data on AS 205N, we also present in Figure 3c a simulation of the AA Tau HCN observations requested, using the known flux from several arcsecond resolution SMA observations.
Correlator setup: The typical line widths are 2-5 km/s. Two correlator setups in Band 7 are used to observe the HCN and CO lines. The last SPW will be broad, both for continuum measurements and improved calibration, and will include transitions of CN and SO. While SO line has not yet been detected in a protoplanetary disk, (sub)mm observations of molecular clouds shows that SO is typically half the intensity of similar excitation CS lines (Nilsson et al. 2000). This would yield another C/O constraint, independent of HCN, H2O, and CO (see Fig. 1 & Walsh et al. 2012).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Here we propose to carry out a 0.4 arcsecond imaging survey of the HCN 4-3 and CO 3-2 lines in a carefully selected suite of protoplanetary disks with intense, well characterized near- through mid-infrared moleclar emission from water vapor, organics, and carbon monoxide. The proposed ALMA spectral line observations will sample the critical 5/10-50 AU regime between the midplane water and CO snow lines at high sensitivity for the first time, and the full data set will accurately constrain the abundance gradients and gas phase elemental ratios throughout the disks. Efficient correlator settings in Band 7 enable isotopologues of CO and HCN to be imaged at the same time as the parent species, along with several other important tracers of disk chemistry. The resulting ALMA image cubes will provide rigorous tests of the first-order patterns expected by thermochemistry in the regions where the bulk of gas- and ice-giant planet formation occurs, while the combined IR/submm data will address the possible roles of the vertical and radial transport of solids in shaping the chemical environment of young planetary systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
